newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore shares dive, index ends at 18-month low.
newsitem.headline: Singapore shares dive, index ends at 18-month low.

text.p: Singapore shares dived in quiet trading with the key Straits Times Industrial index ending at an 18-month low on Monday, dealers said.
The STII fell 31.07 points or 1.5 percent to end at 2,045.58 points, up slightly from an intra-day low of 2,039.16.
"The decline was in response to news that a (recent) government land sale attracted only two low bids and also due to revisions for third quarter growth," one analyst said.
A recent Business Times poll said economists expected third quarter growth to be an average of 3.4 percent, 1.2 percentage points lower than their forecasts in September.
Dealers said the fall was exaggerated by trading error in Singapore Petroleum when one lot exchanged at $$1.08, down 69 cents. The share was last quoted at S$1.63/1.75.
Dealers said falls were especially bad for property stocks but volumes were thin. Total market volume was 69.98 million shares. Losers were ahead of gainers 252 to 78.

Bukit Sembawang headed the losers with a S$1.00 drop on trade of two lots and City Development lost 40 cents to close at S$10.40 with 755,000 shares traded. Several property-related companies, including Straits Steamship and UIC Ltd were traded to a year low. --Raj Rajendran (+65-870-3093)
